Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Collaborative Research: Triggered Aftershocks and Tremors following the Kaikoura Earthquake recorded with Arrays (KEA)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project supports the deployment a dense array of seismic arrays around the Cook Strait in New Zealand to record deep tectonic tremor and aftershocks following the M7.8 Kaikoura earthquake. This was the second largest seismic event since the European settlement in New Zealand, and it triggered deep and shallow slow-slip events along the Hikurangi subduction zone. The ongoing slow-slip events have apparently increased the probability of an M~8 megathrust earthquake in this region. Hence, this network can provide useful information on how slow-slip and tremor evolves on the megathrust following a large earthquake. This project involves international collaborations among United States, New Zealand and China, and will support a junior faculty at UC Riverside.

Four mini-arrays (each has 12 5-s flex-nodes) together with 17 short-period and broadband seismometers, will be deployed around the Cook Strait for up to one year. This hybrid network is strategically planned to complement and take advantage of the existing and planned deployment in the area to be able to have high-resolution locations of seismic events in the region. Seismic data collected during this experiment will be made available to IRIS DMC as soon as the experiment is finished. The collected seismic data can be used to understand the relationship among the M7.8 Kaikoura mainshock, ongoing afterslip, triggered slow-slip events and the accompanying tremor activities, and quantify the physical mechanisms for tremor and microseismicity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to collect a seismic dataset containing a rich variety of seismic events in New Zealand using mini seismic arrays. The time period is a very important factor too. This seismic experiment carried out after the magnitude 7.8 damaging Kaikoura earthquake. This is the time when part of South and North Island are experiencing a ton of aftershocks. In addition, there are evidence that it may have triggered slow earthquakes in nearby faults in New Zealand. We strategically deployed 6 mini seismic arrays to simultaneously record both aftershocks and possible signature of slow earthquakes. The arrays are specifically designed to record both fast and slow earthquakes. This is important because understanding earthquake physics and associated seismic hazards require studying both fast and slow earthquakes in a holistic way.

 

The arrays record data between February 2017 and February 2018, and capture prolific seismic activity. It includes aftershocks activity of the damaging Kaikoura earthquake. Preliminary analyses of data reveal that the data contains signature of slow earthquakes (such as, tectonic tremor) that are particularly hard to detect and locate in New Zealand. Application of array processing techniques on this data may show seismic events that are otherwise not detectable (buried in background noise). Analyses of this unique dataset will allow scientists to investigate the connection between fast and slow earthquakes, how they communicate with each other, and how they transfer stress potentially triggering one another. This has direct implications on our understanding of how faults work and associated seismic hazards. This improved understanding of fault physics may be applied to other parts of the world (like, San Andreas Fault, Cascadia) to better evaluate seismic hazards in those areas.
